abstract.p: For a given function F(x, y), bivariate hyperoseculatory interpolation formulas are obtained by employing a suitably constructed binary nic p<sub>n</sub>(x, y) that is fitted to the values of f(x, y) and its first and second partial derivatives at the m points (x<sub>i</sub>, y<sub>i</sub>) of a rectangular h × k Cartesian grid, where (x<sub>i</sub>, y<sub>i</sub>) = (x<sub>o</sub> + p<sub>ih</sub>, y<sub>0</sub> + q<sub>ik</sub>), p<sub>i</sub> and q<sub>i</sub> are small integers ≥ 0, i = 0(1)m - 1, m ≥ 2. In terms of the variables (p, q), where x = x<sub>0</sub> + ph, y = y<sub>0</sub> + qk (and f(x, y) = F(p, q)), we have p<sub>n</sub>(x, y)= P<sub>n</sub> (p, q). Often, for P<sub>n</sub>(p, q) having a specified desirable form, this problem turns out to be insoluble for every configuration of the points (x<sub>i</sub>, y<sub>i</sub>). When this is not the case, it generally requires considerable investigation to find a pratical configuration of points (x<sub>i</sub>, y<sub>i</sub>) for which there is a solution of the form P<sub>n</sub>(p, q). Formulas are found for choices of P<sub>n</sub>(p, q) and soluble configurations of points (x<sub>i</sub>, y<sub>i</sub>) that have dominant remainder terms in h<sup>r</sup> k<sup>sf</sup><sub>x ... x (r times y ... y (s times</sub> (X<sub>0</sub>, y<sub>0</sub>) whose orders r + s are as high as possible. These two-point formulas, two three-point formulas and one four-point formula, including all remainder terms through the order <tex-math>$r+ s = \lgroup^n, \quad\text{for}\quad m = 2 \\ n + 1, \quad\text{for}\quad m = 3, 4 \rgroup$</tex-math>, are given here in convenient matrix form.
